comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/27331537@N06] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/61271636@N05] 
Did you notice the name of the street heading east from the roudabout? I've marked it with a note ... Warringah Highway! The Warringah Freeway which emerges here now was officially opened in 1968! I'm beginning to think Dr Bradfield was perhaps the greatest visionary ever to work for the NSW Public Service. Incredible!

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/47201412@N02] I wonder if some public servant picked up Bradfield's 1924 plans, dusted them off, and reworked them in the 1950s and 60s!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper] Visionary or megalomaniac?  I think if he had his way the whole city would be covered in expressways, railways, bridges, and wharves, with no room for houses, parks, and people.  Sydney might have become as soulless as Los Angeles.

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content:
This map shows how the Warringah Higway would cut a swathe through Cremorne, and Mosman

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/6033441419/in/photostream/]

The people of Manly-Warringah would have loved it, but I doubt if he would have any friends in Mosman!

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/32162360@N00] He was probably a bit of both!

comment.author: 61271636@N05
comment._content: I would love access to a microscope to make out all the intricate details on the fantastic sketch.

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper] I wonder if Bradfield's 'vision' was too grand for the time, hence the 44 year delay...? [http://www.flickr.com/photos/61271636@N05] I agree, the plan is very detailed. And beautiful. Higher res versions are available for puchase. :) AB

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: Neither of those sketches are much good.  The cars are way too small in both of them.

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: One authentic feature is the chinese church which is still there.

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/mich2009] Neither of the versions are the high res copy. High res are too big to load.

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper] Thanks for adding all those identifying notes!
